Tariffs are designed to shift consumer demand toward domestically produced goods. As foreign products become increasingly expensive, driven by levies such as the Trump administration's 145% effective tariff rate on Chinese imports, consumers are starting to take notice.

Faced with rising prices for foreign goods, some consumers have turned to¬†the internet to determine which products are still made in the United States.

Google Trends data shows "What products are made in the USA?" reached record highs by mid-April, with data going all the way back to 2004.

The White House announced this week that the administration is in talks with 75 countries to secure new trade deals. Trump held discussions with Japan overnight, calling the talks "big progress."

Even as trade deals are expected in the coming weeks and months, the broader objective of the tariff strategy is to reshore critical supply chains essential to national security and to position the United States for dominance in the 2030s. Early internet search trend signs¬†suggest that the tariffs are already influencing consumer behavior - this is a great start.

tweets.text:
Asia Stock Market Update : Monday's tale !

Key negotiations with USA and economic data, Govt support in China and hopes of tariff clarity helped stabilize select sectors. 

Market participants broadly watched for signals from Washington on trade, particularly in shipping, autos, and industrials.

CHINA
Chinese markets climbed to 2-week highs, as Premier Li Qiang called for stronger efforts to prop the equity prices; prompting confidence in state-backed market support. 

Gains were led by non-ferrous metals, which surged +4% as the U.S. dollar weakened and gold hit a record high. 

The PBoC central bank, left key lending rates unchanged, with the 1-year LPR at 3.10% and the 5-year at 3.60%.

JAPAN
Japanese stocks declined amid a stronger yen, weighing on autos and machinery exporters. 

Suzuki Motor, Subaru, Komatsu, and Kubota each fell nearly -4%. 

In another development, Ahresty announced the sale of its unprofitable Guangzhou subsidiary, which faced declining orders due to intensified EV competition from Chinese players.

SOUTH KOREA 
South Korean equities inched higher, buoyed by gains in utilities, banking, & semiconductor shares; though the overall trade remained light ahead of tariff talks and earnings updates. 

Korea Electric Power rose +4.1% and Shinhan Financial Group added +2.2%. 

Jeju Bank at one-point in intraday moves, dropped nearly -5% after announcing a ‚Ç©57 billion Won stock issuance, to fund its operations.
